hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of the tree. Each node has an 'id' and a 'p_id' (parent id). The root node will have a 'p_id' of null, while leaf nodes will not have any child nodes.

Identify how to differentiate between a root, inner, and leaf node. A root node is the only node with a null parent, while leaf nodes have no children, and inner nodes have both a parent and children.
Consider how you can track which nodes have children. You might want to create a set or a dictionary to keep track of all the ids that are present as parents.
Think about how you can iterate through the tree data. You will need to check each node's 'p_id' to determine if it has children or if it is the root.
Remember that the output format requires both the 'id' and the 'type' of each node. You will need to construct a result table that includes these columns.
When processing the nodes, you can use a two-pass approach: first, identify all nodes and their types, and then construct the output table based on this information.
Pay attention to edge cases, such as when there is only one node in the tree. This node should be classified as a root.
You may want to use a dictionary to map each node's id to its type. For example, if you find a node with no children, you can mark it as a leaf.
As you determine each node's type, make sure to handle the relationships correctly. For instance, if a node is found to have children, it should be marked as an inner node.

Finally, ensure that your output includes all nodes in any order, but maintains the required format. You might end up with a structure similar to: [{id: 1, type: 'Root'}, {id: 2, type: 'Inner'}, ...].

questionNotes: The 'id' column contains unique values for each node.
The 'p_id' column can be null for the root node.
Each node can be classified as 'Root', 'Inner', or 'Leaf'.
The output format should include both 'id' and 'type'.
The result can be returned in any order.
